awd_titl_txt: Workshop of ECE Department Heads  "Combating Climate Change: Can it also help the ECE Renaissance?". To be held at the University of Minnesota. April 19-20, 2019.
awd_abstract_narration:
The goal of this project is to conduct a workshop of the Electrical and Computer Engineering (ECE) Department Heads sponsored by NSF and National Academy of Engineers (NAE) on the topic of "Combating Climate Change: Can it also help the ECE Renaissance?" on April 19-20, 2019 in Minneapolis, MN. The proposed workshop program includes presentations by experts on climate change, opportunities to increase female enrollments in ECE courses, an introductory course on climate change and electrical engineering suitable for freshmen as well as high school students, and breakout sessions to prepare an action plan.  The proposed workshop is a positive step towards understanding the linkages between climate change and electrical engineering.  Follow on actions could lead to attracting larger number of high school students including women and minorities towards ECE.

Climate change is happening rapidly, and it poses a great threat to the humanity.  Some of the solutions to combat climate change are using renewable energy to generate electricity, electrifying transportation and increasing system efficiencies, which require the knowledge of electrical engineering. Many young people don't see the relationship between these solutions and ECE. This proposal addresses promoting this relationship and provides an avenue to leverage combating climate change for increasing the pipeline of talented high school students opting for power/energy as well as other related fields within ECE, which could reverse the trend of declining enrollments in ECE programs nationwide.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Climate change is an existential threat, and this message needs to be conveyed to young people in their educational careers as early as possible. Young people are passionate about the environment and climate but don't see the connection that many solutions to combating climate change are ECE‐oriented.   The next step for tackling the climate crisis for them is to get educated to implement solutions. This also presents an opportunity to the ECE field and other STEM fields to attract graduating high school students. These workshops brought together many ECE Department Heads and ECE faculty to discuss the best action plan at this juncture in time.

In particular, the objective of this grant was to hold a workshop of the ECE Department Heads, sponsored by NSF on the topic of "Combating Climate Change: Can it also help the ECE Renaissance?".  The first workshop was held at the University of Minnesota on April 19, 2019. All the ECE Department Heads were invited to this workshop, and if they could not attend, they were requested to send a designated faculty. Another in-person workshop was organized to be held in March 2020 but had to be canceled due to COVID-19. In its place, two online workshops were held on June 5, 2020, and March 8, 2021. ECE faculty were directly invited as well to these workshops.  A total of 279 ECE Dept Heads and ECE Faculty registered for these workshops.

These workshops were announced to the ECE Department Heads of all the universities in the United States. Besides, most of the ECE faculty members in the area of electric power were reached. Therefore, beyond the department heads and the faculty who registered to attend these workshops, a significant outcome of these workshops has been to make them aware that there is a dual-credit concurrent enrollment program in almost all states. It allows university courses to be taught in high schools by high school teachers. Students earn credits to graduate from high schools, as well these credits transfer to the universities offering these courses.

These workshops discussed a course that high school teachers could teach to promote awareness of climate change early on. Given that many solutions are ECE-oriented, it can become a pipeline to electrical engineering programs in which enrollments are declining nationwide. There were invited speakers who spoke on the urgency of combating climate change and various success stories and challenges.  The course of this nature is somewhat open‐ended, and therefore these workshops provided a mechanism to discuss ideas, topics, and experiments for others to implement. 

It also made the faculty aware that a significant amount of material has been developed for the course "Climate Crisis: Implementing Solutions," whose website is http://z.umn.edu/ee1701. This material will soon be available to download free of charge from this website. Many experiments have been developed for an associate laboratory course. This information is also available on the website mentioned above.

These workshops, and the course they promote, are all about having a societal impact. Such a course on environmental sustainability will provide a path to meaningful careers that connect work to community involvement and ethical responsibility. Women, underrepresented minorities, and students across the spectrum will see value in it. At present, in this course at the University of Minnesota, more than 50% of the students enrolled are females, which is highly unusual compared to the rest of the ECE courses. Therefore, such a course can become a gateway course, as a pipeline of students from high schools, to increase the badly needed female enrollments in ECE.

In addition to teaching such a course in all 4‐year colleges and universities nationwide, it can be taught in all 2‐year community colleges nationwide (many of their students transfer to engineering programs at various universities). All of these institutions can then act as a nucleus to spread it in their local high schools. Some of this material may be useable in middle schools and other college courses to solve sustainability‐based problems.  It should be noted that this course does not require the prerequisite of high-school physics, and therefore it can be easily accommodated in the high-school curriculum.
